title: 114_s1251
content:
The Act is titled the "Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Amendments Act" and refers to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act of 1995. It also addresses the representation of the United States under the Convention. The "Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Amendments Act" amends Section 202 of the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act of 1995 to update the representation of the United States under the Convention by making various amendments to subsections related to meetings and councils. SEC. 3. REQUESTS FOR SCIENTIFIC ADVICE. Amendments are made to Section 203 of the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act, including changes to subsections related to Representatives and requests for scientific advice. SEC. 4. AUTHORITIES OF SECRETARY OF STATE WITH RESPECT TO CONVENTION. SEC. 4. AUTHORITIES OF SECRETARY OF STATE WITH RESPECT TO CONVENTION. Section 204 (16 U.S.C. 5603) is amended to align with the procedures in Articles XIV and XV of the Convention. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY COOPERATION. Section 205(a) (16 U.S.C. 5604(a)) grants the Secretary the authority to cooperate with various entities in implementing the Convention and this title. SEC. 6. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. SEC. 6. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES.

Section 207 (16 U.S.C. 5606) is amended to replace "Magnuson Act" with "Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act" and to replace "fish" with "fishery resources".

SEC. 7. CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE.

Section 208 (16 U.S.C. 5607) is amended to adjust numerical formatting and to remove references to "General Council or the Fisheries".

SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS.

Section 210 (16 U.S.C. 5609) is amended to provide updated definitions. The 1982 Convention refers to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. An authorized enforcement officer is someone authorized to enforce regulations under this title. The Commission is the body provided for by specific articles of the Convention. A Commissioner is a US Commissioner to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization. The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in the Northwest is referred to as the Convention. The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries, signed in Ottawa on October 24, 1978, and amended on September 28, 2007, defines the Convention Area as the waters of the Northwest Atlantic Ocean and surrounding regions. The Council mentioned in the document refers to either the New England Fishery Management Council or the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council. Fishery resources within the Convention Area include fish, mollusks, and crustaceans. The term 'fishery resources' in the Convention Area excludes sedentary species under coastal State sovereignty and certain species managed under international treaties. 'Fishing activities' refer to harvesting, processing, transhipping, or any other activity related to fishery resources. "Fishing activities include searching, catching, or harvesting fishery resources, as well as any operation at sea in support of these activities. Exclusions apply to operations related to emergencies." The term 'fishing vessel' refers to a vessel engaged in fishing activities, including fish processing vessels and those involved in preparation for fishing. The term 'Organization' pertains to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization, and 'person' encompasses any individual. The term 'person' includes individuals, corporations, partnerships, and entities. 'Representative' refers to a US Representative to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Scientific Council. 'Scientific council' pertains to the council outlined in the Convention. 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Commerce, and 'State' includes US states, the District of Columbia, and other territories. Transshipment is defined as the unloading of fishery resources from one fishing vessel to another, either at sea or in port. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Section 211 (16 U.S.C. 5610) is amended to change the section number and remove a specific fiscal year. QUOTA ALLOCATION PRACTICE: Section 213 (16 U.S.C. 5612) is repealed.
